channel.title: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient
channel.description:
[u][b]For starters:[/b][/u] A Java based Drive-by is java based application that downloads a file and runs it on your computer. [u][b]- Exemple: [/b][/u] A webclient downloads cache files and run them from you computer right, its easy to thro in a .exe file there and run that aswell, its a huge security leak.
But the drive-by points directly at the .exe file. But You still need to press ACCEPT in order to to allow java to download the .exe file (Mostly)
[u][b]How to see:[/b][/u] Heres a drive-by: [IMG]http://i54.tinypic.com/28u08ly.png[/img] Heres a webclient: [IMG]http://i52.tinypic.com/2uf3bxt.png[/img] [u][b]How to keep you safe[/b][/u] [url=http://hhuu.net]Nod32[/url] [url=http://www.sandboxie.com]Sandboxie[/url] [i]These items has always kept me safe.[/i]

simply look at the jar that’s being loaded as an applet and scan it with BCScanner

item.source: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient

item.title: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“TOMSCAPE BETA, post:7, topic:386566”]It’s nice to see an attempt to cover this.

Though this only covers a small segment of the wider picture, when I went over the SSP checking for infected links such as Java drive bys, many of them used webclients with infected caches or redesigned drive bys.

You really need to be looking at the code, not the images which are on the page. Many servers used a wide range of attempts to cover themselves up.[/quote]
You know, I think I figured out what kept stealing my passwords. I just scanned with Avast and found infected code in a client cache I had…

Read full topic
item.source: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient

item.title: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

It’s nice to see an attempt to cover this.

Though this only covers a small segment of the wider picture, when I went over the SSP checking for infected links such as Java drive bys, many of them used webclients with infected caches or redesigned drive bys.

You really need to be looking at the code, not the images which are on the page. Many servers used a wide range of attempts to cover themselves up.

Read full topic

item.title: [Security] How to know rather its a drive-by or a webclient
item.dc:creator: @uberpk3r uberpk3r
item.description:
@uberpk3r wrote:

Saphire`:

Not necessarily, it’s up to themselves to be careful on the internet. We have no control on what they download, people automatically come to conclusions that runescape private server related items are malicious because its categorized as ‘hacking’.

Very much true, but since they are not that old to have that much knowledge about these things, it can be helpful. I don’t see the harm into letting people know how to kept them safe, I mean I don’t think this forum appreciate all virus on their forum.

Read full topic

For starters:
A Java based Drive-by is java based application that downloads a file and runs it on your computer.
